sentences.sentence: Readers react to the president's Opinion guest essay.

Also: More lies from Fox News; sticking with Tesla; states' abortion bans.To the Editor:Re “My Plan to Extend Medicare,” by Joseph R. Biden Jr. (Opinion guest essay, March 8):President Biden's Medicare plan rightly acknowledges the “rock-solid” role that this core social insurance program plays in the lives of some 64 million beneficiaries and in our nation's overall health care ecosystem.

He takes aim at a range of proposed benefits cuts that he rejects.Among the proposed benefit cuts he did not mention is raising the age of eligibility from 65, where it has been since Medicare's enactment in 1965.

For example, theRepublican Study Committee has proposed“aligning Medicare's eligibility age with the normal retirement age for Social Security and then indexing this age to life expectancy.”As a presidential candidate,Joe Biden campaigned on reducing Medicare's eligibility age.

ANational Academy of Social Insurance studypanel on Medicare eligibility examined various approaches to expanding Medicare coverage.While the president's focus is on bolstering Medicare revenues to extend its long-range financing, we should not lose sight of the need to assess its potential to provide coverage to millions more who still struggle to obtain affordable health insurance.William J. ArnoneWashingtonThe writer is C.E.O.

of the National Academy of Social Insurance.To the Editor:President Biden is absolutely correct in seeking a small tax increase for those making more than $400,000 in order to preserve Medicare until 2050 and beyond.The additional 1.2 percent these wealthy people will pay in increased taxes is a small amount to ask in order to help keep the Medicare fund solvent for many years to come.

Our children and future generations are counting on us to do the right thing, and we must not let them down.Marvin WollRaleigh, N.C.To the Editor:President Biden is right to defend Medicare as a “rock-solid guarantee” of medical insurance for retired and disabled Americans.
He is right to celebrate that the federal government will finally start negotiating lower prescription drug prices and call for expansion of that program.

And he is right to call on Congress to raise taxes on rich people to help pay for Medicare.But with intransigent Republicans in control of the House of Representatives, he also needs an executive branch strategy for strengthening Medicare's finances.

He should start by standing up to the behemoth health insurance corporations that aredefrauding Medicare and overcharging it,according to one estimate, upward of $25 billion a year through the Medicare Advantage program.The Biden administration has proposed some modest reforms.
But it has the legal authority to do much more.

Medicare Advantage was supposed to save taxpayers money compared with traditional Medicare.But it never has.To protect the trust fund, the president should stop the waste, fraud and abuse perpetrated by these corporations.Ady BarkanSanta Barbara, Calif.The writer is an activist for Medicare for All and a co-executive director of the political advocacy organization Be a Hero.To the Editor:President Biden, I totally support your concept to secure Medicare by increasing the contribution from the “wealthiest,” but your definition of wealthy starts from the erroneous assumption that $400,000 a year is equivalent to being a millionaire.

The higher contributions should start with the truly wealthy and not penalize upper-middle-class hard workers.Why should I have to pay the same penalty as a millionaire or the same tax rate as a millionaire?

I am happy to pay my fair share, but not the same as those making huge sums.Helen VernoSanta Monica, Calif.To the Editor:As a senior citizen, I'm grateful to President Biden for focusing on Medicare and how vital it is to the tens of millions of Americans who rely on it.It is also important to the sons and daughters of senior citizens, who would be called upon to assist Mom and Dad if Medicare benefits were sharply curtailed.Whether we identify as Democrats, Republicans, progressives or conservatives, affordable health care benefits are crucial to all of our lives.Alice Reiter LabyValley Stream, N.Y.Undeterred, More Lies From Fox NewsTo the Editor:Re “White House Rejects Claims From Carlson as 'Shameful'” (Business, March 9):Given all the recent revelations of how Fox News repeatedly lied to the American people in support of Donald Trump's false claims of a stolen election, one might think that the very public acknowledgment of fault by their executives would result in a pivot to more truthful reporting.But no, Fox is doubling down, in a preposterous attempt to rewrite our history of the violent Jan. 6 attack on police officers, the Constitution and the rule of law that the whole world witnessed as a simple peaceful visit by tourists to our Capitol.Fox News may be earning its just deserts in court.David PedersonExcelsior, Minn.'I'm Sticking With Tesla, Warts and All'To the Editor:“A 120-Year-Old Company Is Leaving Tesla in the Dust,” by Ezra Dyer (Opinion guest essay, March 7), comes down hard on Tesla's yet-unfulfilled promises and on Elon Musk.

But Ford is not “leaving Tesla in the dust”; it's scrambling to follow a revolutionary company that still leads the field ᅳ or actually, several fields.Tesla doesn't just make beautiful cars; it makes an ecosystem to run them: charging stations, solar panels, home- and utility-scale battery storage, and software that integrates these assets with the grid.
This is in service of Tesla's mission, “to accelerate the world's transition to sustainable energy.”The world desperately needs that mission to succeed, so I'm sticking with Tesla, warts and all.
I love my Model 3, even as I am dismayed at Mr. Musk's tweets and politics.

My highest priority is fighting the climate crisis, so I'm choosing to live with these contradictions.Stephanie DobaBrooklynTo the Editor:It's bizarre for Ezra Dyer to conclude that Ford is leaving Tesla in the dust.
Ford sold approximately 61,000 electric vehicles in 2022, while Tesla sold more than 1.3 million.

It's true that, as Mr. Dyer points out, Ford sold 15,617 F-150 Lightning pickups last year, while the production of Tesla's Cybertruck has been delayed, with mass production to start next year in an effort to fulfill the 1.6 million reservations reportedly placed for the Cybertruck.However, it's extremely unlikely that in the foreseeable future either Ford or any other vehicle manufacturer in the Western world will come close to selling as many E.V.s as Tesla.Michael M. ShermanWynnewood, Pa.States' Abortion BansTo the Editor:Re “Roe's Fall TurnsNorth Carolina Into Destination” (front page, March 5):The scenario described in this article illustrates a primary result of states' abortion bans: not a notable reduction in abortions, but rather delayed ones, occurring later in pregnancy, with greater risk, cost and distress for women in need.Until “pro-life” activists recognize this reality and fully support free contraception and access to all reproductive health services, they will continue to work against their own convictions, while causing harm.Is that really what they want?Steve HeiligSan FranciscoThis article appeared in print on page A23.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

He takes aim at a range of proposed benefits cuts that he rejects.Among the proposed benefit cuts he did not mention is raising the age of eligibility from 65, where it has been since Medicare’s enactment in 1965. ANational Academy of Social Insurance studypanel on Medicare eligibility examined various approaches to expanding Medicare coverage.While the president’s focus is on bolstering Medicare revenues to extend its long-range financing, we should not lose sight of the need to assess its potential to provide coverage to millions more who still struggle to obtain affordable health insurance.William J. But Ford is not “leaving Tesla in the dust”; it’s scrambling to follow a revolutionary company that still leads the field — or actually, several fields.Tesla doesn’t just make beautiful cars; it makes an ecosystem to run them: charging stations, solar panels, home- and utility-scale battery storage, and software that integrates these assets with the grid. This is in service of Tesla’s mission, “to accelerate the world’s transition to sustainable energy.”The world desperately needs that mission to succeed, so I’m sticking with Tesla, warts and all.
